text:
Good evening, or good
morning, depending on where you are in the world. I am Jim Matheson, a Professor
at Harvard Business School.

And it is a pleasure
to be with you tonight. I know there are
many of you out there that are serving in uniform,
or have served in uniform,

and we have a bunch of
veterans on the panel. And so thank you
for your service. And we're really going
to spend time tonight

helping you think about the
decision to not just leave active duty, but to transition
to your next way of serving,

your next career, through
getting an MBA-- in particular, an MBA at the Harvard
Business School. So that's really the
goal for the next hour

is for me to facilitate
a conversation with a great collection
of first year MBAs, all veterans, that
are finishing up

what we call the required
curriculum at Harvard Business School. So we're going to dive
into that in a minute. I made my transition
from active duty.

I was a US Navy F-14,
F-18 pilot, and that was in the last century. Actually, it was
the last Millennium,

so it's been a while-- late '90s, I was Class of 1987 from
the US Naval Academy,

and Class of 2001 from the
Harvard Business School. So I've been through
this transition.

And one of the real pleasures
of being on the faculty at HBS is working with our veteran
community, the Armed Forces Alumni Association, and
some of the great students

that we have on. So what we're going
to is we're going to talk a little bit
about the arc of-- the whole decision process.

So the five vets that
you see in front of you have made that transition. They're now sitting
in classrooms at HBS

in Cambridge, Mass, and now
they're on to other decisions about what do they do for
their summer internship, what do they do with the
rest of their lives?

But it hasn't been
so long, either, for me or for these
folks when they were sitting in your
seats, in your shoes,

trying to make the
decision about what to do with their next steps in
their careers moving forward. So we'll get some good insights
and perspectives from them.

A couple of other comments
before we dive in. First of all, we got a
bunch of great questions from the registration, so
we'll try to weave those

into our conversations. So thank you for those. There's a Q&A function
on the webinar. If you have something that's
just a burning question,

go ahead and pop
it into the Q&A. And we're getting
some right now. Thank you, Jorge,
John, appreciate that.

We'll try to weave
those in, as well. And then tomorrow
night, if tonight's not

enough of excitement,
enough of an HBS fix for you all, tomorrow night I'm
going to have the pleasure of leading a case conversation.

And we'll actually
have our veterans in one of our HBS classrooms. We'll be zooming
you all into that, and we'll be going
through a real live case

conversation, which is the core
way that we do the teaching and learning at HBS. It's a fantastic way to learn.

We'll hear from our
veteran students here in a moment about what they
think about the HBS classroom. I can tell you, it's
a fantastic and really

challenging and interesting
way to teach, as well. So that's tomorrow night. I think Jane and the team
have already sent that out

to everyone. If you have questions, please
hit us up in the chatbox. But we'll look forward to hoping
to having you there tomorrow

night. All right. With no more ado, let's
turn to our panelists.

And what I've asked
them to think about is, a lot has happened for them
in the past 12 to 24 months

when they were
sitting in your shoes, and it's been a
bit of a whirlwind. Because you come to
HBS and it's just-- you get pulled into
this amazing environment

and you get all these new
experiences, these new friends, these new challenges. But I've asked them to
meditate and go back

to when they were sitting in
your shoes and thinking about, what do I do? Do I get out? Do I stay in?

If I get out, what do I do? Those are all the
questions I had. So we're going to dive in
to that question to start,

and also is a way for you to get
to know our veteran panelists. So I'm going to go
right down to the list. Chris, why don't
you get us started,

and if you can remember
back to your decision point. Yeah. Thanks, Jim. So for everyone on the panel,
My name is Chris Lowman.

I was in Naval Academy
Class of '14 graduate. Served in Marine
Corps for seven years,

so just one year shy of
getting 100% of the GI Bill.

I think for me, a whole
multitude of factors really played-- played a part. Like one-- like right here,
right, like I've got a--

I have a kid. I've got a wife. I'm married. And so as I finished
my service, I

think what really
came down to is what's best for
me and my family. And the military
lifestyle for me

just wasn't really
there anymore so I looked for different
transition opportunities. And everyone's going to have
a multitude, whether that's

going straight into industry,
or taking a leave of absence,

or going into-- getting a higher
education degree. And as I looked at it, I
mean, there just really

wasn't a better place than
Harvard Business School. And that doesn't mean I
didn't apply to anywhere else, but I was fortunate enough
to get into Harvard.

And once I did, there
just wasn't a question of the matter as to
where I was going to go and what I was going to do
based on the opportunities

that it was going
to create for me and my family moving forward. So that's really
where I'm at, Jim.

I appreciate the time
and thanks, everyone, for being here. Thanks, Chris. And we'll come back and touch
a little bit on the application

process after everybody made
the decision to actually lean in to coming to HBS. We'll pick out some of the
wisdom of that process,

as well. So, Kristin, a little
bit about your decision. And you're in a kind
of a unique program,

so maybe you can frame
a little bit of how you apply to the dual degree.

Yeah. Thanks, Jim. So my name is Kristin. I was a Class of 2013 from
Boston University ROTC,

and then I was in a Surface
Warfare Nuke in the Navy. And so for me, I knew based on
some of the lifestyle demands

that I wanted to
get out of the Navy. And I knew that I wanted
to go to grad school. And so I was starting to look
at job listings on what degree

is going to be most
advantageous for me. And I started to
see a trend where it would always be MPH, or
MPP, or whatever else, or MBA.

And I realized that this
MBA gave this insane amount of optionality and
different fields

as I wanted to move forward. And then like you
already alluded to, I found the MS/MBA
Biotechnology.

So Harvard has an
MS/MBA in Engineering, as well as one in
Biotech Technology.

Once I found that,
it was really kind of no question that was 100%
what I wanted, because it gave

me the technical and science
expertise that I wanted to delve into something deeply,
in combination with the MBA,

and that total optionality. Yeah. Thanks, Kristin. And I'm sure folks know, but
you can get a joint law degree,

business degree, so a JD/MBA. You can go to the Kennedy
School and get an MPP and MBA
or MPA-ID/MBA. It's telling me my AirPods-- are you hearing me OK?

My AirPods are misbehaving here. You can also get a
dual degree, as Kristin

is doing, where you get
an Engineering Master's and an MBA. So there's different
options at HBS.

What we don't have is we do not
have an Executive MBA program. A lot of Exec Ed, but
unlike other schools,

we don't offer an executive. So there's only
really one way to get an MBA at HBS, and
that's to be somehow
part of a two year program. Awesome. All right. EJ, tell us your story.

Thanks, Jim, for the panel. I'm EJ Coleman. I'm a West Point
Class of '16 graduate, and I was a Field Artillery
Officer in the Army.

I served five years-- so my
minimum time-- out at JBLM in Washington State,
Joint Base Lewis-McChord.

And I was coming up on the point
where you have your captain, you're getting ready to go
to captain's career course.

There's a long lead time to
come in command, and then a lot of staff in the near
future, which didn't seem

like the most exciting to me. And so I knew it
was time to pivot in my career field of choice.

I had a lot of
mentors who had gone kind of the military
and then the MBA route. And the ones I
really looked up to

had also gone to HBS, which
kind of encouraged me to apply. And I knew it was
the right decision. When I got accepted, a
lot of the senior officers

that I worked with when
I told them I got in, they were like, well,
obviously, you need to go do that because there's
more than one way to serve.

But it seemed like
a great opportunity. And just the option-- I mean, as the other
panelists already alluded to, the options that HBS
opens up for you is just

kind of something that I
hadn't experienced before, and I love the
experience so far. So I'm excited to
talk more about it.
Great. Thanks, EJ. Christy.
Hi, everyone. Thanks, Jim, for having me. It's nice to meet you all. My name's Christy.

I'm a 2013 Naval Academy
graduate in Annapolis. [INAUDIBLE] in the
backseat of the F-18 Super

Hornet, which I loved. And then I'm now in the MBA
program and absolutely love it.

Kind of similar
considerations as Chris, so I have a one-year-old son
named Oliver, who is my light

and is also a
really big handful. So I think when I was
trying to make the decision, I was also weighing where
is best for my family.

And I think, ultimately,
HBS is a very soft landing. It's a very warm blanket to
wrap yourself in and just

like really open my eyes to
all the different opportunities that are out there. Kind of also part
of my calculus when

I was making the transition was
the fact that my husband, who is also a Naval
officer, was getting out

around the same time, really
wanted to go to law school. So we were basically
doing the Venn diagram, applying to schools
in every major city,

and seeing where we overlapped. And Harvard was, by far
and away, I thought, the best option for our
family, and the one that I was

really, really excited about. So looking forward to
talking more later. Thanks for having me.

Awesome. Thanks- thanks, Christy. Orry, last, certainly
not least, tell

us a little bit about your
transition decision and story. Of course. So my name is Orry McDonald.

I am the co-President for
Admissions for the HBS Veterans Club. So if you ever launch an email
over to the Veterans Club,

it comes to me. And then I'll put you
in contact with people within our organization
who can help you decide if HBS is for you.

My background-- I went to the
University of Mississippi. So for any non Academy
types out there

who think the door might
be shut because you didn't go to the Academy,
that's certainly not the case.

There's a couple of
us actually here, so there's a good path for that. I did eight years in the
Marines as an artillery officer.

And then towards
the end of my time, I think a lot of junior
and mid-grade captains can kind of relate to
the feeling of seeing

the next like 12 to 15
years of your life laid out in front of you, kind of you're
looking into a crystal ball.

Like you don't know
where you'll be, but you know what
you'll be doing. For me, that made
me uncomfortable,

but I didn't know what I wanted
to do after the Marine Corps. So it was like a
really easy transition.

I gave myself some lead
time with my EAS, launched a bunch of MBA apps, was very
fortunate to get into HBS.

And then as Christy said,
it's a super soft landing, easy transition
with the GI Bill.

You really can't go wrong. And I've been tremendously
happy with my decision to be here at HBS.

Awesome, Orry. Thank you all for
that first pass. So there's some
common themes, right? And I would say that it's easy
for us, the current students,

and probably really easy
for me in retrospect, to go, oh, of course,
it was never a decision. I was always going to
go to business school

and always go to HBS. Even now 23-- 4 years later after I made
the decision, I do remember--

I was more senior so I was
at 13 years of active duty. I just made 05. I was an F-14, F-18 pilot.

I was going to go command
a Hornets quadrant, and that was my goal. And medically, I
couldn't do that

so I-- really, for me, all of a
sudden my world got shaken up. But it was for sure
a big decision,

even with that, to leave
the active duty, generally, because I think
we all enjoyed it. You heard there's a
lot of challenges,

a lot of opportunities
inside the military. So the answer is not
always just to get out, but a big part of that answer
is what would you do next?

And I think you heard
a common theme here that HBS is just such
a wonderful transition mechanism to almost
anything you want to do.

We'll talk about what some of
those downstream paths are. A couple of things in the
Q&A I want to just highlight.

So there's a set of folks
who are asking about the case conversation tomorrow night. If you could put your
email in the Q&A,

and Jane's going to
make sure that we get some information out. We got a lot of folks signed
up for it tomorrow night, but I think we can
probably fit some more

folks because it is Zoom. And then there's a couple
of really great questions about being a veteran in
the application process.

We'll come to that in a minute. But in general, every HBS
class has about 4% veterans.

And so the HBS courses
are pretty large. So that the RC class that
these five folks are in

has 1,060 students in it. So it's the biggest first
year HBS class we've ever had.

That's partly a
function of COVID. But if you do the math,
basically, something like 40 or 50 students in
every class, or veteran.

So HBS has a long and
really positive and storied history working with the
US military and Department

of Defense. And so there's a really-- I mean, it's a very
veteran friendly, really,

veteran leaning school. Not all MBA programs
are as friendly as HBS, but I think most,
certainly, would say that.

There's a great question
about enlisted versus officer. So most of the-- I mean, all of us here came
from the officer's report.

But we definitely have a
few select prior enlisteds-- love that. Of course, you need a college
degree to come to HBS.

But we have currently in joint
Kennedy School MBA program a special operator from the SEAL
community who's prior enlisted,

and we've had a
couple of folks who come out of the Special Forces
community, in particular. So there's definitely
room for that,

and I think that would be a
real standout application. And the other thing
you'll see, I think, from successful veteran
applicants is service not

so much mattering, but that
people did real things, like operational experience,
leadership experience,

especially, folks that
are Post-9/11 Veterans, combat veterans, all those types
of experiences really help you stand out because it adds a
nice additional complexion

to the classroom where you have
a lot of other folks who manage budgets and done consulting
projects with the veterans

bring our real operational
leadership experience in difficult situations. So the more that
you have, probably

the more your
application is going to stand out relative
to other applicants, and definitely, other veterans.

So let's talk about the
application process. Let's go-- let's go in
reverse order real quick.

What is the single
best piece of advice you got that you followed that
actually worked as it relates

to, so now you've
made your decision, you're in the
pipeline, you're doing all that stuff you've
got to do to apply.

Orry, what was the single
best piece of advice you got? So for me, the best
piece of advice I got

was to apply round one. Anecdotally, I have no idea
if that affects anything.

But I was told in no--
in no uncertain terms to apply round one as a
veteran and that your odds

of getting in would go way up. And so I just-- I made it happen. I applied round
one, ended up here.

And so I have to believe
that that was true. And so that's my advice
to a lot of veterans, as well, is to
apply in round one.

Got it. Christy? I would like to
underline Service

to School, by far and away. By now, y'all have heard of it. If you haven't, it's
veterans who are usually

recent or current MBA students. I think they all stood
up for law school. And they'll do
application reviews

or your personal statements. Mine was really helpful in
mock interviews with me-- really an incredible service.

I think they went through
like 16 drafts of my resume. Very patient soul.

Service to School,
give it a quick Google, thought it was really helpful. That's awesome.

I will tell you,
there's so much more squared away, thanks
to Jane and the team and the current students.

We just started the Armed
Forces Alumni Association when I was at school
in the late '90s. And I would say there's
so much more support now.

And so lean into it. Orry mentioned AFAA. Christy's talking about
Service to School. Some really good programs,
you should really get the help
because it's there for you. EJ. Yeah.

I think the biggest
piece of advice I got was be prepared to
retake the GMAT or GRE.

Know your strengths, know the
difference between the tests and play to that,
which is something that I definitely had to do.

I took both test multiple times. But just be ready to take
it, so start it early and get a few reps in it.

And then once it's
done, you can focus on the rest of the application,
which is really the meat of it. Got it.

Kristin. Yeah. I think the biggest thing for
me was don't self-select out.

So I'll very specifically
say that to all the women that are on the
call, and I think there's other groups that
need to hear that, as well.

But a lot of us
think that because we don't align with the
traditional business school path

that we don't
deserve to be there. And I think that just knowing
that you do deserve to be there

and that you owe it to
yourself to do the steps and take the time. It's literally free.

All it costs is
some of your time. And so don't self-select
out and go for it.

Yeah, Kristin, I love that. I mean, approaching 40%
of each class are female.

So, I mean, the female
veterans or female students do amazingly well. There's a lot of diversity.

We have 40% international. So the student body at HBS
is extraordinarily diverse.

And I love that, don't
rule yourself out. And I say, also, I think that
the whole process of thinking

about getting out and applying
to school, it's a process. It helps you get
clear on whether you

want to leave active
duty or not, and if you want to go to HBS or not. Just because you get in
doesn't mean you have to go.

So I think the whole
process of really examining where you are in your life
and what matters to you and doing the hard
work, I think,

is a really, really good
step no matter what you do. Chris, full circle back to you.

Yeah. I think Orry's going to
hate me for this one, because his email box
is about to explode.

But, I mean, you have to
reach out to the Vets Clubs at every school
you're applying to.

They have-- I mean, they're
the ones that have gotten in. They have the insight. They can help you
with your resumes. They can help you
with your essays.

And each school is different, to
be completely honest, in terms of how they view things. Some schools have-- some
Vets Clubs have actual say in

whether or not
you get in or not. Harvard is not one
of those, right? But we do have insights that can
help get you into this school.

So flood Orry's email
inbox and you'll

get connected with
a veteran that can help shape your package.

So what about-- I mean, one
of the pieces of advice that I give to anyone that will listen
and I try to remind myself

of it is, how you
leave something is almost more important
than what you did

while you were there, right? And I know a lot of you
out there are thinking, well, I'm in a job, my unit,
my country, everyone, really

is relying on me. And that's true, we are. And it's sometimes really hard
to give ourselves permission

to make that transition. If it's time for you
to leave active duty, there's other ways. I stayed in the reserves.

I'm sure some of our folks
here-- if anybody-- anybody else is doing reserves? Yeah.

So, Christy, I'm going
to come back to you in a minute, maybe just share
how that's worked for you. I thought it was really
interesting, very challenging.

I certainly found it challenging
to balance that, especially, after I graduated HBS and went
on to start and run things.

But giving yourself
the permission, if this is the
time for you to go do something different,
to go do that.

But as a group reflects on your
transition out of the military, was anything that you would
have done differently or better

in actually buttoning up
that part of your life, whether it's leaving
your unit, or just sort

of being done with military
and then moving on? And then-- I think it
was Orry and Christy, I'd love to hear about
your reserve stuff.

So EJ, Chris, or Kristin,
any advice on buttoning up that part of your life?

Yeah, I can go first. I mean, I think what it
really comes down to is, like you don't want to
burn bridges, right?

But at the same time,
you need the space to ensure that you can
get your applications and get your resumes done.

It-- so it's all about balance. It's a balancing act as
you close out your time. And then the other
thing I would recommend

is that in trying
to set yourself up for success for business school,
look at the programs that

are available for you. DOD SkillBridge is
probably the one that I would recommend the
most where it gives you an addition-- where
it gives you six

months of your life--
of your active duty time to basically go out and get
some real world experience. Like making the transition
into business school,

it's actually kind of hard
from an academic standpoint, because so many
people are coming from private equity,
investment banking, consulting,

that they have-- I'm not going to
call it a leg up, but they have experience and
exposure to certain things that you just won't have.

So if you can take six
months of your time and go try and land Goldman
Sachs Integration Program,

or you can go try and land
time at a venture capital firm to start getting exposure to
some of these other things,

you start to develop
like fundamentals within the business-- within the business
framework sense

that will put you
on a path to success no matter where you go in life. So that would be
my biggest thing.
Yeah, I love that. Thanks, Chris. EJ, anything to add, or Kristin? Yeah. I would just say--

I think one thing I did as I was
already thinking about applying to business school is, I let
my supervisor and team know

that, hey, this is what
I'm thinking to just get their support and buy in. Because that also helped
with kind of leaving aspects.

You never want to leave
anything worse off than when you arrived. But once I got it, everyone
felt invested kind of

in that success, as well. And those are still people that
I have connections with today. So just kind of making
sure you don't blindside

your team with like an
application to business school, or like saying you're
going to get out. Just let your
intentions be known.

And what I found is
more often than not, people will be very
accepting and supportive.

Christy, what's it been
like in the reserves? It's been good.

I loved my time in
the Navy so I didn't want to throw in
the towel just yet and so I stayed in reserves.

It's been pretty flexible. I think it really
just comes down to open communication
with your unit. I'm currently
assigned to the NOSC

in Quincy, Mass, which is like
maybe a 30 minute drive away. And, yeah, I'm just
sort of like-- when

I've had other commitments, I've
been able to work with my CO and reschedule my drills
for maybe like days

that I have off from school,
and things like that. So I think every situation
may maybe be a little bit different, but--

yeah, it's been great. Great. And Orry, you, too, are
in the reserves, right?

Yeah, that's correct. So I'm in-- I'm in Fort
Anglico down in Florida. It hasn't-- I haven't found
it to be too challenging.

It's kind of a unit where you
can work around the schedule, in a sense, so it's
not super strict.

I've had to miss a few days
of school here and there, but by and large,
it's not a big deal. And I've appreciated retaining
that tie to the military

because staying in the
reserves in the near future is something that's
important to me. So it definitely has
not been a deal breaker.

So if anybody is
considering the reserves but thinks that MBA programs are
not feasible while doing that,

just hit me up and
we can talk about it. But it's definitely-- it's in
the deck of cards to do that.

Got it. Let's talk about you've been
accepted, you're coming,

you show up at HBS. If you were to wind it
back, is there anything

that you would have
done to prepare better for that first class that-- maybe take-- I had to
take a couple of semesters

of accounting out in beautiful
Fallon Community College out in Nevada, which was great.

I'm glad I did that. But is there
anything you wish you would have done to prepare
yourself now that you're a year into the experience?
EJ, you're smiling. What do you think? Yeah. I was at the core--

like HBS CORe, so
you get accepted and then they give
like three modules. It's like accounting,
finance, and leadership.

I'm probably butchering
the three subjects, it's been that long ago. It feels like forever. But I would have definitely
paid a little more attention

to that core curriculum
than I did, because it's not great to do it at your
own pace and you're supposed to finish it
by a certain deadline.

And we all know
like sometimes you might push things off when
you're on terminal leave. And I probably could have
paid a little more attention

to accounting, because
I've had to go back during the school year and
rewatch some of those lessons. So the thing I would
have done is probably

taken it a little more seriously
and taken a few more notes to make the academic year
just a little bit easier.
I second that. Yeah.

When-- they don't do it
anymore, but when I showed it, they actually did like
a 10 day program for,

we called it diversity camp. But basically, it was all the
non bankers and consultants came from-- which
was a great program.

It was the most fun because it
was the tails of the diversity curve, and they sort
of got us focused.

I think there's
now a lot of stuff that they do online,
as EJ suggests, that you can do online,
either through HBS.

HBS online has a ton of
courses that you can take. And there's just so much
stuff on the internet now for you to get pulled up.

For those of you
that don't know, there's a great website
called Poets&Quants, which is just sort of the whole
world of the MBA application

process. So there's tons and tons of good
scoop on Poets&Quants, as well, about the application process.

And there's lots of services
that can help, as well. Anything else any of the other--
any of the other panelists that

would do something different,
or something you did do that you're glad you did?

No? OK. I think we're sort
of squared away. Other than EJ, everybody
is doing great here at HBS.

Let's talk about money. So most of you, other
than reservists,

are not working for
a couple of years. You might get paid a little
bit for your summer internship. How did you-- how did you think
about the financial equation,

what financial aid is available? How did you actually just--
how did you just square the corner-- opportunity costs, real
cash, and how you managed

to live while you're at school? Kristin, how have you
thought about that? Yeah. So I'm on 100% GI Bill
with the Yellow Ribbon,

so that means for real talk,
it's about a $3,000 check that I'm getting each month.

With my living and
housing situation, that covers a pretty decent
amount of most things.

HBS students tend to travel
a lot, and so some of that

is coming out of my savings. But that's a choice
that I'm making. And then kind of the opportunity
costs long-term thinking is--

I actually heard
somebody the other day talking about a lifetime
graph of your finances.

We're probably at the
ultimate low right now. We're at the graph minimum.

And so there's some
short-term exchanges that have to be made, but very
likely they will absolutely

pay off in the long term. Other-- other either
programs or the ways

that you thought about the
financial bit, or access capital?

Yeah, I'll jump in. I would say if
you're transitioning, like take advantage of--

if you feel like you need to
apply for a VA disability, like definitely knock that out.

The Benefits at Discharge
Program is phenomenal. I did not do that and so I had
to wait a considerable amount

of time to get a rating. But it is a little bit
of extra money per month that really helps out a lot.

And apart from that, I'm in
the same boat as Kristin-- GI Bill, savings.

It's kind of-- we're
just trying to keep cash flows as negative--
as positive as possible

for the next two years. Or as little negative, I
think, is really what you mean. Yeah, I was trying to--

I was trying to think
out a phrase that is as least negative. Yeah. And Kristin brings up
the point, which is the--

HBS is like a frenetic
social environment. I mean, that's
part of it, right? You're coming here to learn

you want to do with your life. But you're really coming

and that help you achieve

But there's a lot of-- there's a lot of

Julie, my wife, and I, we were

Technically,
unemployment benefit but can be utilized to

So let's talk about
the classroom. So we've gone through all this. We've made the

We've applied,

And what was the
experience like? So, Chris, we'll start with you. Like did you-- what was
the-- if you remember

the first week or two
of being on campus, like what was the feeling,
and how did you kind of work

through that? Yeah. I mean, I think the
benefit of being a vet is that we're so used to
moving around all the time,

and we're so used to just
joining different communities at different stages
of our life that it's

really easy to kind of-- it's very-- I think it's
easier for us to transition because we come in with a

which is the Veteran
Community, right? Like the Veteran Community
is there 100% of the way

as you're making your
move into Cambridge, or whatever school
you decide to go to. And I think that a lot
of people have a harder

you up to be a little bit more outgoing.

It frees you up to
be a little bit more confident in the classroom. And you see that people--
there are stark differences

between those of
us that have had to make these drastic changes
in our lives over and over again, that it kind of enables
us to almost be thought leaders

in the first few
weeks of class, even when you don't
understand finance, or you don't
understand accounting. And those are the ones that we--

I think most of us would feel
the least confident about. But it kind of gives
you the opportunity

to stand out in the first
few weeks as someone who is used to new circumstances
and new experiences. But that's just my experience,
and maybe some people

can echo based off that, or

Probably not enough would

between my last day

in uniform and my first

reading a whole bunch

of academic papers. And in that middle, I was

But I think kind of like Chris
was saying, no matter what, you still have this

And so even though

Christy, let's talk about the-- we get into the
actual classroom.

So one of the things that's
particularly unique about HBS

is the pedagogy, which
is a fancy way of saying how we actually learn.

And almost everything we do as
a professor and as a student is the case method. So it's Socratic.

So, essentially, we
sit in this classroom, there'll be somewhere 80, 90
students, sometimes smaller,

but that's kind of your
core group, the hive brain. And my job as the
professor, basically, is to facilitate a conversation.

I don't lecture. I don't-- I try not
to answer questions. It's all about facilitating
the conversation among these 85

folks, and all have
different perspectives. But the common thing they
have, as they all will have, hopefully, prepared their case.

And the case is 10
or 15 pages long. It's sort of-- it always
starts with this thing, well, EJ was looking out
the window and trying

to make a big
important decision. And then it frames
all the stuff that EJ wishes he had known to
actually make that decision.

So you literally, by the end
of your two years at HBS, you do hundreds and
hundreds of these cases.

And you get-- by this point
at the end of the first year, these five are getting pretty
good at-- almost too good. They're getting sloppy,
I'm sure, at this point.

But go back to
Christy, that first day in the section,
the first case, how

was that experience for you? It was crazy. I think that was kind of the
moment my mind got blown.

So HBS does like a
week at the beginning called Start Week
where you're just with your kind of,
essentially, homeroom advisor.

And it kind of gets you
accustomed to the case method. But it's a good welcome,
because I just remember sitting there that day-- I think it was a case about
Pepsi and the Pepsi CEO.

And, literally, every
hand went in the air with the first
question of the day. And it was like a
little overwhelming

And then you hear
everyone talking, and it's just incredible. Everyone is so smart. Like I came to Harvard,
obviously, knowing everyone

would be incredibly brilliant
and like top performers in their field. But to see all 90 people
sitting at your left and right with really
intelligent things to say

and interesting
contrarian views, it gets really inspiring, and
maybe a tiny bit intimidating.

But I think it has to
come back to the Vet value prop, that we have operational
experience, that we have leadership experience,
and playing to those strengths.

So that was, yeah, just
like a mental image that I think I'll have
for a long, long time. Yeah.

It's been longer for me. I remember it well. One tip I will tell you is that
Veterans disproportionately

get cold-called in the
early parts of the section.

So in your first year,
your required curriculum, you literally are with the same
85 people the whole semester.

You're in the same seat. You get to change
twice at the holidays. So you're literally--
I call it homeroom.

You're like in your homeroom
with the same people. And by the end of
that semester, you know everybody's
little isms-- who

worked for General Electric
Company, and who did this, and who did that. And everybody knows the
military people, as well.

But you do get cold-called early

So the HBS MBA program is two
years, separated by a summer.

And that summer, almost
everyone uses for what we call a summer internship. We heard earlier
you can actually

focus-- you can potentially
do like a pre-internship. I've seen folks and Veterans
use that really effectively

to get even like two months
in a commercial setting before HBS can be
enormously helpful.

But the focus truly is-- the first thing that
the students need to do

is get integrated, get
into their section, start performing. And then pretty
quickly, like October

at the latest, all of
a sudden, the pressure starts turning on like, what am
I going to do with my summer?

And that certainly connects

of mechanism process

set of pressures
around what are they going to do for that summer. So, EJ, talk a little bit about
like how did you approach that?

What support did you get? How did you make your
decision for the summer? Yeah.

So I think kind of coming
into HBS, couple of my mentors like, hey, look into
management consulting.

So going back to the pre-- it wasn't a pre-internship,
but they have summer programs before you actually
matriculate in the fall

to start for like
the consulting firm. So I did that to help. And then HBS, thankfully--
not every school does this--

but they have a blackout period. So when classes start
August through October, there's no recruiting.

So there's not a
lot of pressure, which is actually very nice. But then, as you said, once
October hits, it ramps up.

And I think there
was the real test of how do you balance
your time, because you

have to prep for classes. You still want to do
the social aspect. But now, you have this kind
of recruiting strain, which

is more about meeting
people, having coffee chats, trying to understand
the firms that you might be interested in.

And I think that the resources
that HBS has, and then I also got through the Armed
Forces Alumni Association,

were enormously helpful. Like we do retreats and kind
of Armed Forces Alumni events. And there you can
talk to people who

just went through that
process, and they can kind of-- they were able
to tell me, hey, these are the events you
really need to get to.

These are the events you
probably need to skip and this is where you
need to probably focus your time as a Veteran. And so I'd say, for me,
throughout the entire

recruiting process, being able
to leverage kind of the ECs, or second years, who went down
the path that I was trying

to go, and just getting that
feedback and learning those lessons from them-- instead of
having to learn the hard way--

I think, contributed--
attributed to my actually attending an internship
early, which was a huge weight off my shoulders.
